div.p:
I think my dear Mrs Brinkley I may firmly
believe that you have never received a little
note from me expressing my thanks and Lucy's
for the roots you were so good as to send here - So
let me now begin by saying that we are very much
obliged to you for recollecting us - and hoping they
may brilliantly and sweetly received us of you &
the dear Observatory when this horrid writing weather
leaves us - and Spring returns to us once more
Since the above was written our delayed post has brought a
letter from my sister and we are all shocked and grieved to hear
that the fever has got into that dear Observatory - and that so
many of your family are suffering from it - I trust in
God that their valuable lives may be spared and that
you dear Mrs Brinkley will escape without taking it-
How happy dear Sally must be at having her father with
her! I had heard from my brother and sister Beaufort
that they had been to see you at Cloyne and that both
you and the Bishop were pleased with your residence and
with the people around you and that the climate had
agreed wonderfully well with both - Indeed the
climate in the South is any mild and very charming.
Here we have had the most odious weather interminable
winds and snows in impassable drifts - The Lawyers
& judges of the N. W. Circuit have been much delayed
& much annoyed by the difficulty of making their way
to Cavan - But what is worse many wretched crea
turescreatures who have the fever and had taken shelter in
huts by the side of a limekiln or hedge have
been nearly snowed up or covered with Snow drifts -
Yet strange to tell they are now recovering - while
those who were in good houses and in better circum=
stances circumstances have died of it!
William had happily crossed the sea before the
Storms arose - and we have had two cheerful letters
from him from Liverpool where he will soon be very
busy - I rejoice that Harriet had the happiness of
meeting you at my
aunts aunt's
- I had not a notion that
so much time could have passed since she last saw
you - but since she says so it must be right - She seems
to have enjoyed the meeting very much
Careys account I will write out on the other side
I hope his improvements have been found "worth
the money" - for what line of life is he intended?
Should you happen to know of any other person
to fill his place at the school and at Mrs Blacks she
will be most thankful for him on the same terms
as Careys or more properly for £12 British pr
per annum - She has room for two -
Will you have the goodness to remember me
most affectionately to the good Bishop and to my friend Sally
div.closer:
Believe me always your obliged & affectionate
F Edgeworth

postscript.p:
I have pinned together the Receipts for
the last year - and the new Bills. I
have put with to the account which I hope
you may find correct -
Is Dr McDonald to be the Observer?
I have not mentioned Lucy about whom you are
always so kindly interested and of whom I can
that she is going on well and becoming stronger every
day - as I hear, for she has been for the last six weeks
with her sister Sophy Fox.
Tell the Bishop if he has leisure to listen
to the gossip of a letter that Francis is very com
-fortably comfortably settled at Cambridge - He has not got rooms
but says he has a tidy lodging with a good bed - and a
very pleasant sitting room - and that he says he enjoys
his solitary studies and his regular hours very much
and has not yet been kilt by Algebra or Mathematics
My dear Mrs Brinkley - I send you a little
packet containing three little rings which were
made I understand at
Cary's Carey's
request for you by
the daughter of the people with whom he boarded while

he was here -
I am glad my dear Mrs. Brinkley that William
had the pleasure of seeing you all before he went
off to Liverpool - The poor dear Observatory
I am afraid he has now been at the last time -
I am sure you are taking happiness to
Cloyne - which ought to comfort us for our
loss - Believe me dear Mrs. Brinkley
Your affecte
affectionate
Honora Edgeworth
